reviewText: Vintage serial movie western action at its 50ish decade best.

THE SERIAL "DON DAREDEVIL RIDES AGAIN. YOU HAVE KEN CURTIS WHO DID A GREAT SUPPORTING ROLL ON GUNSMOKE. A GREAT MIXTURE OF CO-STARS, ROY BARCROFT, ALINE TOWNE,AND LANE BRADFORD.  I REALLY ENJOYED THE SERIALS I HAVE ABOUT
TEN TO FIFTEEN SERIALS. ALSO AMAZON KEEPS ME INFORMED.

Republic Pictures present "DON DAREDEVIL RIDES AGAIN" (1951) (167 mins/B&W) (Dolby digitally remastered) --- is a 12-Chapter Republic Movie Serial starring Ken Curtis, Aline Towne, Roy Barcroft and I Stanford Jolley , relive those thrilling days week after week venue brought you to the theater, as you were mesmerized in your seat waiting for the final chapter ... exciting action within 12 episodes the Republic Serials department, riding once again is Ken Curtis in the guise of Don Daredevil, who is a masked avenger by night to thwart Roy Barcroft (Republic's King of the Badmen), with the help of favorite character actor I. Stanford Jolley (who is in Barcroft's hip pocket) who gives all the Serial cast some episodes to die for.

Under Fred C. Brannon (Director), Franklin Adreon (Associate Producer), Ronald Davidson (Screenwriter), Stanley Wilson (Original Score), Ellis W. Carter (Cinematographer), Cliff Bell Sr. (Editor) ------ the cast includes Ken Curtis (Lee Hadley/Don Daredevil), Aline Towne (Patricia Doyle), Roy Barcroft (Douglas Stratton), Lane Bradford (Webber), Robert Einer (Gary Taylor), John L. Cason (Hagen ), I. Stanford Jolley (Sheriff), Hank Patterson (Buck Bender), Tom Steele (Henchman Black), Jack Ingram (Jack, Bartender #2), Bud Osborne (Bartender), Gene Roth (Caleb Brown), David Sharpe (Henchman Clark), Forrest Taylor (Pop Taylor), Dale Van Sickel (Dan Farley) ------ the plot line has Roy Barcroft with forged Spanish land grants as he and crooked Sheriff I. Stanford Jolley plan to take over the local ranches in the territory ... Aline Towne and her neighbor Robert Einer are up against the Barcroft swindle, but wait is there no hope for them and other ranchers ... could there be a masked daredevil who will thwart all the baddies at Republic Pictures, yes indeed there is Ken Curtis in the guise of Zorro becomes "Don Daredevil", champion of the underdog ... almost two out of three episodes a saloon gets the worst of it with fight scenes by the Republic stunt personnel Carey Loftin (stunt double: John L. Cason), Eddie Parker (stunt double: Roy Barcroft), Tom Steele (stunt double: Ken Curtis), Dale Van Sickel (stunt double: Robert Einer) can Don Daredevil rescue and prevail once again, certainly a cliffhanger if ever I saw one ... the suspense is riveting inclusive with exciting scenes as everyone is having fun with this classic ... don't leave the theater until the final chapter "Flames of Vengeance" ... another winner from the vaults of Republic Serials --- this is a must watch for the serial buffs in all of us.

CHAPTER TITLES:
1.  Return of the Don
2.  Double Death
3.  Hidden Danger
4.  Retreat to Destruction
5.  Cold Steel
6.  Flaming Juggernaut
7.  Claim Jumper
8.  Perilous Combat
9.  Hostage of Destiny
10. Marked For Murder
11. Captive Witness
12. Flames of Vengeance

BIOS:
1.  Ken Curtis (aka: Curtis Wain Gates)
Date of birth:  2 July 1916 - Lamar, Colorado
Date of death:  29 April 1991 - Fresno, California

Special Footnote, Ken Curtis an American actor began his show business career as a singer in the big-band era, and was a vocalist in the legendary Tommy Dorsey orchestra ... entered films in the late 1940s at the tail end of the singing cowboy period in a series of low-budget westerns for Columbia Pictures ... the genre died out he turned to straight dramatic and comedy parts, and became a regular in the films of director John Ford (who was his father-in-law) ... Curtis is best known for his long-running role as Festus Hagen, the scrofulous, cantankerous deputy in the long-running TV series "Gunsmoke" (1955) --- Inducted (as a cast member of "Gunsmoke" (1955)) into the Hall of Great Western Performers of the National Cowboy and Western Heritage Museum in 1981.

BIOS:
2. Roy Barcroft (aka: Howard Harold Ravenscroft)
Date of birth: 7 September 1902 - Crab Orchard, Nebraska
Date of death: 28 November 1969 - Woodland Hills, Los Angeles, California

Second Special Footnote, actor Roy Barcroft one of the most sought after badmen of the Saturday Matinee era --- His face appeared in more westerns than any cowboy villain who rode the range in the '40s and '50s --- an complete account of "Roy Barcroft:King of the Badmen", which is the title of Bobby J. Copeland's book on the life and times of "Republic Pictures Number One Villain". Barcroft appeared in B-Westerns and Serials - became one of the most recognized actors, when you heard that familiar voice --- you were in for it. Roy was one of the few bad guys that once you saw his name in the credits, you were going to get your money's worth. Barcroft was my first favorite and my second was Harry Woods, who in many ways reminded me of each other --- I remember watching Barcroft in a variety of Republic Serials --- "Manhunt of Mystery Island" (1945), as Captain Mephisto --- "The Purple Monster Strikes" (1945), as the invading Martian --- "G-Men Never Forget" (1948), a dual role as the honest police commissioner and the lead villain (good & bad look-alikes) --- "Don Daredevil Rides Again" (1951) --- "Radar Men from the Moon" (1952), as Retik --- My favorite B-Westerns were the casting of Wild "Bill" Elliott and Allan "Rocky" Lane vs the under handed dealings of Roy Barcroft, boss, leader of the gang or henchmen --- every frame was B-Westerns at their best --- With knock-down-drag-out fight scenes that gave you everything you ever wished for and more in an action film --- fellow actors, producers and directors all agree Roy Barcroft was as beloved as anybody else in the Motion Picture business.

If you're into vintage serials as I am, why not pick up a copy of the following titles from VCI Home Video:

Hats off and thanks to Les Adams (collector/guideslines for character identification), Chuck Anderson (Webmaster: The Old Corral/B-Westerns. Com), Boyd Magers (Western Clippings), Bobby J. Copeland (author of "Trail Talk"), Rhonda Lemons (Empire Publishing Inc) and Bob Nareau (author of "The Real Bob Steele") as they have rekindled my interest once again for B-Westerns and Serials --- looking forward to more high quality releases from the vintage serial era of the '20s, '30s & '40s and B-Westerns ... order your copy now from Amazon where there are plenty of copies available on VHS, stay tuned once again for top notch action mixed with deadly adventure --- if you enjoyed this title, why not check out VCI Entertainment where they are experts in releasing B-Westerns and Serials --- all my heroes have been cowboys!

Total Time: 167 min on VHS ~ Republic Video ~ (6/16/1998)

As a small child I could not sleep on friday nights because the next chapter of "Don Daredevil" would be showing the next day at the local picture show.  As a confirmed "front row kid" I saw all the serials of the time and this one stands out in my memory as one of the best.  I cannot say that this is good adult fare but it is one of the best of the genre.
This is sort of a restart for Zorro Fans. It is based on the Zorro stories and re invented . The usually good story line and interesting plot. Good  entertainment for the fans of this genre.
